coredata.dc:title: Crystallization of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene
coredata.dc:creator: Long, Nguyen Truong
Huy, Huynh Anh
Tuan, Truong Quoc
Le, Ong Kim
Van Hoang, Vo
Giang, Nguyen Hoang
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Crystallization under isothermal condition of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene (a-silicene) models has been studied via molecular dynamics (MD) simulation with Stillinger-Weber (SW) interaction potential. Supercooled liquid and a-silicene models containing 104 atoms are obtained via the rapid solidification process from the melt. At each given temperature below and above T
g , models are annealed from 5 ns up to 8 ns in order to investigate aging effect on two-dimensional structural arrangement of disordered Si-atoms. Time dependence of thermodynamic and structural quantities is analyzed including potential energy, radial distribution function (RDF), coordination number, buckling degree, ring and bond-angle distribution. We find that 2D-crystallization of supercooled liquid and a-silicene exhibits a first-order behavior. Time-temperature-transformation (TTT) diagram exhibits a commonly nose-shape by analyzing a wide temperature range from supercooled liquid to amorphous state. High critical cooling rates of a-silicene are found indicating low glass-formation ability of the system. Thermodynamic properties of crystallization of silicenes attained after-aging are studied in details and we clarify a novel scenario of crystallization. A homogenous tendency of natural quenched-in nucleation atoms aggregate into larger clusters in 2D Si supercooled liquid sheet. Consequently, a polycrystalline layer of silicene is developed with decent low-numbered chain defects as grain boundary. In contrast, crystallization of a-silicene shows a partial crystallization behavior: Crystal clusters are found to exhibit a heterogeneous growth in models obtained below T
g . Crystal formed from a-silicene is a quasi-equilibrium state with a large number of defects still existed in models after a long relaxing time.

Crystallization of amorphous 2D materials
Aging effect

The effect of aging on the structural properties of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: The evolution of potential energy of 2D supercooled liquid and amorphous models at various temperatures as a function of relaxation time. Time for phase transition of each temperature is shown by value t* on the graph.
Radial distribution functions of aged models obtained at 750 K (top) and 1650 K (bottom) in comparison with those unrelaxed models. Inset: Reduced RDF of second peak of correspondent models.
The evolution of mean ring size and mean coordination number (inset) upon annealing at various temperatures.
Ring statistics of crystallized models at two annealed temperatures (750 K and 1650 K). Inset: Coordination number distribution of models at 750 K and 1650 K.
Bond-angle distribution of crystallization models for temperature ranged from supercooled liquid to amorphous region.
2D visualization of the atomic configurations of crystalline silicene models at 1650 K (a) and 750 K (b).

The distribution of atoms in a given coordinate in the z direction (buckling) of crystallized silicene at 750 K and 1650 K compared with a-silicene obtained in [16]. The dot lines are the edge of the buckling.
Calculation of critical cooling rate for 2D silicon.

head.ce:title: Crystallization of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
Crystallization under isothermal condition of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene (a-silicene) models has been studied via molecular dynamics (MD) simulation with Stillinger-Weber (SW) interaction potential. Supercooled liquid and a-silicene models containing 104 atoms are obtained via the rapid solidification process from the melt. At each given temperature below and above T
g , models are annealed from 5 ns up to 8 ns in order to investigate aging effect on two-dimensional structural arrangement of disordered Si-atoms. Time dependence of thermodynamic and structural quantities is analyzed including potential energy, radial distribution function (RDF), coordination number, buckling degree, ring and bond-angle distribution. We find that 2D-crystallization of supercooled liquid and a-silicene exhibits a first-order behavior. Time-temperature-transformation (TTT) diagram exhibits a commonly nose-shape by analyzing a wide temperature range from supercooled liquid to amorphous state. High critical cooling rates of a-silicene are found indicating low glass-formation ability of the system. Thermodynamic properties of crystallization of silicenes attained after-aging are studied in details and we clarify a novel scenario of crystallization. A homogenous tendency of natural quenched-in nucleation atoms aggregate into larger clusters in 2D Si supercooled liquid sheet. Consequently, a polycrystalline layer of silicene is developed with decent low-numbered chain defects as grain boundary. In contrast, crystallization of a-silicene shows a partial crystallization behavior: Crystal clusters are found to exhibit a heterogeneous growth in models obtained below T
g . Crystal formed from a-silicene is a quasi-equilibrium state with a large number of defects still existed in models after a long relaxing time.

ce:list-item.ce:para: Amorphous and supercooled state of 2D silicene exhibit a first-order transition with annealing process.
Critical cooling rate of amorphous silicene is found in range of 2.36 × 1011 − 4.95 × 1011 K.s −1.
2D silicene obtained via isothermal annealing has broadened angular distribution and homogeneous low-buckled degree.
The relaxation of supercooled liquid phase will produce a high-refined crystalline silicene.
The crystallization from amorphous state will yield a crystalline-amorphous coexistence phase.

ce:section.ce:para: Pristine silicene, a buckled honeycomb one atomic layer thick form of silicon – one of the major electronic industrial applied components, exhibits exceptional characteristics and morphology for a variety of applications, including ferromagnetism, half-metallicity, quantum Hall effect, giant magnetoresistance, optoelectronics, spintronics and superconductivity [1–9]. Silicene succeeds allotropic affinity of bulk silicon so that they can be more easily integrated into existing electronic devices, reducing those devices into the nano-regimes. Furthermore, natural electronic band structures of low-buckled silicene not only resemble those of graphene which benefits from its ultrahigh charge carrier mobility, but also prevails over its carbon analog: By applying external electric and magnetic field or inducing specific adatoms defects, buckled silicene structure offered a tunable band gap which can solve the gap issue of graphene's zero gap at the Dirac cone in logic applications. Stronger spin–orbit coupling is another prominent advantage of silicene in spin and anomalous quantum Hall effect experiments. Motivated by astonishing properties and enormous technology potential application, buckled 2D pristine silicene structure has under focused investigations by computer simulations and experiments [7–10].

However, disorder states like amorphous and supercooled liquid of 2D silicene are not fully understood while amorphous silicon has already been renowned as a chosen material of large areas of microelectronics [11] and the amorphous state of 2D honeycomb graphene are under extensive studies (see [12] and references therein). In fact, evidence of the experimental existence of amorphous silicene structure has been noticed recently by [13]. Some works of DFT calculations [14,15] and MD simulation [16] are also carried out to reveal disorder structure of freestanding amorphous silicene layer, but our understanding of a-silicene nanoscale structure and atomic behavior is very limited. In general, it raises some objectives which fascinate our interesting in the investigation of amorphous and supercooled liquid state of two-dimensional silicon by MD simulations:
(a)
In particular, two interesting features determined the unique electronic band structure of silicene are defective structures and buckling degree distribution [17,18]. A detailed MD simulation in [16] reported a strong distorted honeycomb-like and defective structure of amorphous silicene. In addition, the similar buckling characteristic along with higher concentration of adatoms, Stone-Wales and vacancy defects reveal the possibility of amorphous silicon to be a natural 2D semiconductor. On the other hand, the disorder phase like amorphous or supercooled liquid is not stable, it will continuously evolve to a high-ordered phase under ubiquitous phenomenon called “aging” [19]. In the case of silicon-based material, it is detrimental to applications. Henceforth, it raises the first motivation about exploiting aging stability of amorphous silicene and other disorder phase of the 2D silicon structure when annealed at a constant temperature. Our work there is not only to verify the crystallization of the disordered state of 2D silicon, but it also concerns the annealed condition for production desired silicene sheet which may play an important in the designing of novel material. It is worth to note that crystallization of amorphous carbon proving to be the key in the synthesis of large area, homogenous, single layer graphene with the homogeneity of the graphene film [20]. Metal-catalyzed crystallization of amorphous carbon to graphene by thermal annealing is demonstrated in [21]. They fabricate graphene sheets with control thickness by the thickness of the initial amorphous carbon layer and resulted quality is comparable to CVD synthesis method. Another experimental and MD simulation study announced catalyst-free growth of graphene from amorphous carbon (a–C) by current-induced annealing: They found that a rearrangement of amorphous clusters into graphene at high temperatures on a graphene substrate or from the edges of the holes. Their finding could discover new avenues for atomically smooth template-supported processes of graphene or other 2D materials [22]. Similar crystallization of other 2D amorphous carbon formation, such as nanotube is confirmed by L. Ci [23,24]. The graphene layers in the annealed carbon nanotubes form a uniform two-dimensional turbostratic stack, and improvement effect on hydrogen storage capacity of annealed carbon nanotubes is approved.
(b)
The second question is what will aging affect on macroscopic structure and thermodynamics properties of the two-dimensional continuous random network? Disorder-to-order transition mechanism in aging phenomenon is one of the most intriguing aspect in condense matter. On their 3D analogue, transition of amorphous and supercooled liquid silicon to the crystalline phase has been under long-term explored by a number of experimental and simulation studies [25–33]. The studies of amorphous Si crystallization by MSC and CVD methods show that crystallization active energy is 2.24eV and the total enthalpy of crystallization is equal to 11.9 ± 0.7kJ/mol [25,26]. An overview study of kinetic fragility and thermodynamic fragility for various liquids class using Arrhenius plot and excess entropy versus T
g -scaled is nominated by M. Martinez and A. Angell [28]. An anomalous behaviour of SiO2 is found and explained by the vibrational entropy of silica glass is much less than those of the crystalline polymorphs. They suggested that the origin of variations in the fragility of liquids causes of the differences between their vibrational heat capacities and relates to behaviour of low-energy modes near and below the boson peak. A numerical theory review of Kob claimed that glass-forming liquids divide into “strong” and “fragile” glass formers: The strong glass former shows an Arrhenius' law dependence while the latter one shows strong deviations from it. The temperature dependence of the relaxation dynamics in the case of Lennard-Jones and the silica system is extensively analyzed by computer simulations and the validity of Gibbs-DiMarzio theory and mode-coupling theory are mentioned [29]. Molecular simulations in [30] are reported a picoseconds time-scale scenario of aging of silica and the generalized structure function during aging parts obeys a t/t
r scaling scenario. Based on [31], they found that the inherent structure of vitreous silica depends on the duration of the relaxation process and at temperatures close to T
g the system takes advantage of the relaxation process in order to find lower energy minima. Besides, MD simulation of A. Kerrache et al. [32] elucidated the dynamical heterogeneity presence and their increment during the aging process in supercooled silica. Recently, theoretical progress in the description of glassy relaxation and aging are reviewed for the supercooled liquid and amorphous of network-forming materials such as Si and Si-based oxides [33–35]. For instance, a thermal equilibrium below T
g of amorphous silica network with tetrahedral coordination introduced a homogeneous network with higher stability and better mechanical properties. The rearrangement of paracrystalline nuclei and nanocrystallite is distorted up to disaggregation due to the natural requirement to equilibrate the free energy among the atoms [34]. Likewise, an analyzation of supercooled liquid silicon address a first-order phase transition, from a fragile, dense liquid to a strong, low-density liquid with nearly tetrahedral local coordination [35]. A brief summary of M. Micoulaut discusses the important role played of network topology and rigidity for the understanding of the physics of aging and emphasized the simulation utility on probe the dynamics at the molecular level [36]. In this respect, it would be interesting to consider the effort to characterize and understand the nature of two-dimensional systems of glassy materials such as silicene or germanene for which our work here is attempting to clarify.
(c)
Finally, the progress of DFT, AIMD and MD simulations are performed to explore the self-rejuvenation of defective sites on pristine silicene when it is annealed for a long time: It finds that multi-vacancies defects on silicene can undergo coalesce with each other and the fragmentation into smaller vacancies, thus form vacancy clusters. In addition, defective silicene on Ag(001) substrate has a lower energy only when it contains mono-vacancies and di-vacancies [18]. A related tendency of vacancy defects in silicene is detected in [37]: This trend and the presence of Si adatoms stabilize the entirely silicene system. The formation energy of vacancy clusters can be dramatically decreased when they arrange in a line and form extended line defects. Moreover, three distinct monovacancy formations, stabilities and reconstructions are calculated by first-principles study in 2D low-buckled silicene. Two most stable monovacancies lead to metallic behavior of the system and an existence of the vacancy-induces localized states in them is found [38]. In [39], atomistic mechanisms in the self-healing of various types of vacancy of single-layer graphene and silicene are identified. It pointed out that electronic and magnetic properties are modified by reconstructing by vacancy defects in both graphene and silicene. Two more remarkable results are discovered: adatom supply increases perfect hexagonal structure rejuvenation and Stone-Wales defects are likely formed in the course of healing of silicene vacancy. In brief, because of limitation of ab-initio calculation, present approaches are gaining only microscopic information about the transformation of small defect sites on the pristine silicene so that it gets a macroscopic picture of large-clusters irregularity ring's activities under aging process.

Accordingly, a comprehensive MD simulation of crystallization behavior of notable supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene is our intention. This is an outstanding choice to gain a deep insight into molecular-scale events of this important 2D material or explore astonishing properties to bring a new generation for material in the high-tech industry application.

Our initial model is a stable silicene model containing 104 Si atoms with the same buckling of 0.44 Å and a bond length of 2.28 Å (i.e. the most stable low-buckling silicene found in DFT calculations [40]). Periodic boundary conditions (PBCs) are applied only in the x and y Cartesian directions while in the z direction a fixed boundary with an elastic reflection behavior is applied. The initial configuration size is L
x × L
y × L
z = 335.571 × 193.742 × 0.44Å3. The length of the model in the z direction equals 0.44 Å (i.e. 0.22 Å above and below z = 0) and fixed for the whole simulation procedure. The atoms in our model are interacted via the Stillinger–Weber (SW) potential as follows:
(1)

All parameters of SW potential are taken from the original version which details can be seen in [41]. SW potential has been widely used for the simulation of Si or Si-based systems for the last 30 years [16,42–46]. Our previous investigation on crystalline silicene obtained from quenched melts using this potential gave a melting/freezing temperature, which is close to that found experimentally for bulk Si [42]. Moreover, we already found that upon cooling from a high temperature, 2D liquid Si with this SW potential can solidify into 2D solid state with both graphene-like honeycomb and amorphous distorted structure [16,42].

In order to obtain the formation of a-silicene and supercooled liquid from 2D pristine silicene model, we use the same calculation procedure employed in [16]. Chosen models from 750 K to 1650 K (below and above T
g = 1350K found in [16]) is annealed for a long time in order to study time-induced crystallization. The Verlet algorithm is employed, and NPT ensemble condition with zero-pressure is used for simulation procedure. The temperature is corrected via simple velocity rescaling. Our simulation uses LAMMPS software with Nose–Hoover barostat implemented for controlling the pressure [47]. ISAACS software is used for calculating the ring statistics [48] and VMD software (Illinois University) is used for 2D visualization of atomic configurations [49]. A cutoff radius of 3.0 Å is taken to calculate the coordination number, bond-angle and interatomic distance distributions in the system. This cutoff radius is equal to the position of the first minimum after the first peak in the radial distribution function (RDF) of models obtained at 300 K. For the calculation of rings, the ‘shortest path’ rule is applied [48]. We also average the results over two independent runs to improve the statistics.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The thermodynamics and evolution upon annealing
ce:section.ce:para:
Our atomic configurations obtained at various temperatures above and below T
g = 1350Khave been isothermally annealed after an incubation time t = 5ns(e.g. from 1650 K to 750 K). The evolution of the structure and some thermodynamic quantities of the system upon cooling from the melt can be seen in Figs. 1–4
. Universally, the amorphous and supercooled liquid phase is very unstable, so that they will start to crystallize when relaxed at constant temperature. This effect is usually recorded by a decreasing in the potential energy of the system. Therefore, the time dependence of the total energy per atom of the system is investigated in Fig. 1 in the annealing process of all our models.

The transition between unstable supercooled liquid and amorphous states to crystallization state of 2D silicene exhibits common trends: The potential energy of the unstable systems in supercooled liquid and amorphous has spontaneously transit toward a lower point of energy of more stable phase. This instinctively phase-shift demonstrates a two-dimensional time-induced crystallization of amorphous and supercooled liquid of silicene. As seen from Fig. 1, the potential energy of system after-aging oscillates around a defined value after a time of phase transition (t*), so the system reaches a stable crystalline phase. A strong drop of potential energy upon annealing for 1–2 ns is related to the crystallization of the system (Fig. 1). Note that crystallization of supercooled liquid and amorphous states often exhibits a first-order phase transition with a clear sudden drop of potential energy. Two-dimension of the system often blurs sudden change in potential energy of the first-order transition like that found in the present work (Fig. 1). A similar trend has found for crystallization in previous simulations of the 3D amorphous Si by MEAM-L and SW potential [50,51], supercooled liquid Si with Tersoff potential [52] and other amorphous materials of Ni, Pb, Fe, Fe thin films and nanoparticles [53–57] and alloys Ti-Al, Cu-Al-Ni, Ag-Cu, Zr-Cu [58–61], one-component amorphous system and amorphous H2O [62,63].

Further information about the aging effect is inferred from comparison between the tendency potential energies of our system with other simulations of 3D silicon [50–52]. The initial fluctuation stage, before switching to crystallization transition which commonly seen on in supercooled liquid and amorphous models [52–57], is not observed in our simulations. Instead of that, the monotonous decreasing of system potential energy related to annealing induced-crystallization of 2D supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene occurs almost immediately after relaxation. For example, one can see that the potential energy of 1650 K model (supercooled liquid phase) is rapid declined from high potential energy state at 2.88eV/atomdown to a potential basin equal to 2.97eV/atom after 1 ns. With longer annealing, the potential energy of the system continues to decrease, but the drop rate is slower until it reaches to a potential basin at 2.98eV/atom. Finally, the system potential energy fluctuates around 2.98eV/atomafter 4 ns relax, which introduces a stable crystalline state. Note that the time of crystallization of the model at a given temperature (denoted as t*) is defined as a starting point of linearity of annealing time dependence of potential energy after its strong drop in the initial stage of annealing (Fig. 1).

For low-temperature annealing, annealing-induced crystallization of 2D silicene is quite similar to that of high-temperature. The necessary time of crystallization of the amorphous state is also equal to that of supercooled liquid (from around t = 1.4ns to around t = 2.27ns). The potential energy also decreases slowly down to a lower energy point in the same manner, but the difference in energy is quite limited (potential energy of the model at 750 K decreases only 0.3eV/atomwhen crystallization occurs). Lately, energy of models below T
g is highly fluctuating around an equilibrium value, implying that system enters a partial crystalline state.

As described above, annealing-induced crystallization of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene can be drawn as follows: (i) the initial 2D atomic configurations of supercooled liquid or amorphous matrix are very unstable so that the monotonous decrease of energy occurs until the system reach a temporary lowest energy of random network phase; (ii) The followed second stage can be predicted as a first-order transition toward the ordered-configuration, i.e. amorphous-crystal transition; (iii) The final third stage is the relaxation of the crystalline sample. Similar monotonous decrease of potential energy as function of annealing time was found previously by experiments and simulations of amorphous Si bulk at various temperatures around room temperature [50,51], solidification of silicon atoms on silicene surface [64] and other amorphous metallic glasses such as Pb [54], Cu-Al-Ni [59], some incompatibility stages of evolvement energy with incubated time in both supercooled liquid and amorphous region is found for other 3D materials [52,53,55–57,60–63]. The understanding of the discrepancy of phase transition between 2D and 3D substances is of great interest and thus further investigation in this direction for other 2D materials is recommended.

In the present work for crystallization of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene, we report one of the most interesting problems is the time-temperature-transformation (TTT) diagram which has a nose shape like that found computationally and experimentally for various metals including Ni, Fe, Pb, etc. [53,54,56,60,65] or metallic alloys [66–69] or 2D simple monatomic system [70,71]. As shown in Fig. 2, we find the shortest incubation time required for crystallization of 2D glass-forming silicene is equal to t ∗ = 1.06nscorresponding to the temperature of T = 1250K. Note that position of the nose in the TTT diagram for crystallization of supercooled state is a measure of a glass-forming ability of a material. The TTT diagram is often considered as a powerful aid in predicting the final structure obtained by continuous cooling of the melt at a constant cooling rate.

Applying the method described in [72] with our data of 2D a-silicene, we can estimate the critical cooling rate (
γ C
=
T m
−
T nose
t nose
with T
nose = 1250K and t
nose = 1.06ns) necessary for occurrence of glass transition. Note that melting point for 2D silicene is only predicted at around 1500 K–1775 K by MD simulation with ReaxFF potential [73] and SW potential [42] or by MC with Tersoff potential [74], we still have no melting point verified by experiments until present. Therefore, using all those calculated T
m above for testing, we estimated critical cooling rate for 2D silicene in Table 1 .

The critical cooling rate found above for 2D silicon is quite high, indicating a low glass-forming ability of the 2D silicon. Nevertheless, one can actualize the amorphous state of silicene by ultra-rapid cooling techniques such as vapor condensation onto a cryogenic temperature layer (1011 K ⋅ s−1) or ion implantation (1014 K ⋅ s−1) and access TTT diagram for crystallization of 2D a-silicene in experimental time scale [75]. Moreover, we hence conclude that a-silicene has noteworthy thermal stability, which can open the possibility of using it throughout the silicon microelectronics industry.

Other information of thermodynamics of crystallization of supercooled liquid and a-silicene can be seen via the analysis of evolution of radial distribution functions obtained during isothermal annealing. In Fig. 3, we show the RDF of amorphous and supercooled liquid 2D silicon altogether with those aging models after t = 8ns relax. All peak height in amorphous model slightly changes with aging, but the peak position is still remained constant. As suggested in simulation data [51,57,71], we can conclude that it is also very difficult to detect the effect of aging of amorphous solid 2D silicon on the average quantities such as RDF. The secondary peak is the most apparently changed in RDF in aging of a-silicene as concerned of 3D silicon counterpart in [51], we note that the slightly shrink and intensity rising of this peak can be related to reconstruction of high ring-size defects into lower ring-size structures.

On the other hand, one can see that RDF changes during the aging time of supercooled liquid have noticeable different shapes as follows: After isothermal annealing-induced crystallization in the supercooled liquid model, there is clearly rising of typically subordinate peaks for pristine silicene in RDF. The positions and low-height of these peaks are similar to those found for the silicene in both simulations and experiments [18,74,76] and close to hexagonal silicon thin film in [77]. The position of the first RDF peak, which is considered as the mean interatomic distance of the crystalline silicene in our models obtained by annealing at 1650 K and 750 K is located at 2.35Å. The mean inter-particle distance values calculated with all models are found within the range from 2.28Å to 2.50Å proposed for silicene [78,79] and close to the bulk Si-Si distance value at 2.35Å [79]. The discrepancy between final atomic configurations of crystallized models obtained from the supercooled liquid region and amorphous state may be related to the differences in atomic mobility and the effects of different proportions of defects of the parent configurations. It is also easy to verify that more perfect 2D honeycomb structure of silicene can be obtained from aged supercooled liquid state while time-induced crystallization of amorphous silicene is not completely achieved even in the case that low annealing temperature aging is taken.

We present evolution of the structure of the system upon cooling from the melt via the temperature dependence of the mean ring size (MRS) and mean coordination number (MCN) in Fig. 4. First, the MRS plot of all models has a tendency to escalate with short initial relaxed time and continues by a slower increment with longer incubated time. The evolution of ring-size accompanies with a reversed declining trend of MCN from high coordination number (
Z ¯
> 3 ) to around
Z ¯
= 3 of hexagonal silicene. Two distinct plots above confirm the growth of supercooled liquid and amorphous states toward the crystalline phase by the auto-rearrangement of high-coordinated atoms and low-numbered rings, like that found in the liquid-crystal transition of graphene and silicene models [42,80]. For pristine silicene, the buckled hexagonal rings are dominated for all atoms in the system while all atoms are neighbored with three different atoms so that the observation of similarity in MRS and MCN of each temperature aged model indicates some remarkable points as follows:
(i)
The final configurations of crystallization in the temperature region above T
g are closer to a perfect crystalline structure of silicene if temperature is higher. 3D amorphous and supercooled silicon is well-known as precursor material for the rapid thermal annealing in order to fabricate a perfect structure and smooth surface morphology silicon using in high-performance semiconductors. This technique may also be applied to manufacture the 2D silicene for electronic devices and this leads to the importance of our simulation result on the synthesis and fabrication of this new semiconductor material.
(ii)
In contrast, an opposite tendency is happening in the temperature region below T
g : A decent higher MCN and low-numbered rings mean that the well-ordered structure of a perfect crystalline silicene is still not recovered in configuration after annealed. Therefore, we can predict that the defects in low-temperature amorphous silicene are very stable with thermal annealing, which maintain the ability to control bandgap of a-silicene when one integrates it into semiconductor devices based on Si materials at normal temperature condition.
(iii)
Sudden increase of MRS and decrease in MCN occurred at various incubation times of our calculation data exhibits a discontinuous behavior which is related to first-order transition. None of annealed models reaches a perfect value MRS = 6 of the hexagonal silicene sheet so naturally recrystallized silicene from supercooled melt and amorphous state will contain some specific defects and distorted structures which can be investigated in the next part of our paper.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The effect of aging on the structural properties of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene
ce:section.ce:para:
We next address the final relaxed configurations to verify temperature dependence of structure of models crystallized by analyzing some important distributions. With the prediction of the difference between crystalline models above and below the glass transition point as reported before, we examine detailed the coordination number distribution and ring statistics of aging models obtained from the amorphous phase at 750 K and supercooled liquid phase at 1650 K in Fig. 5 . One can see that coordination number distributions and ring statistics of models crystallized at two temperatures are different from each other. Note that we use R
cut−off = 3.0Å for calculating of coordination number and “shortest-path” rule method for determining ring size of crystallized models. Some interesting points about 2D time-induced crystallization can be stated here:
(i)
The fraction of atoms with coordination number Z = 3 and atoms of the ideal six-membered ring is higher in models crystallized in the supercooled liquid region compared to that crystallized in the amorphous one points out that the crystalline order of 2D silicene crystalline order is enhanced with temperature of annealing like that discussed above via analysis of RDF, MCN and MRS (Fig. 3). Unlike liquid-crystalline transition or 3D counterpart crystallization of amorphous silicon, it is worth to note that the coordination number Z = 3 cannot discriminate accurately between 6-fold and 5-fold rings because the pentagonal ring may contain both threefold and fourfolds-coordinated atoms depending on the reference central atom. Therefore, the information provided by the coordination number distribution is not reliable for investigating of amorphous-crystalline transition of 2D silicene. This reason explains the different peak heights of the coordination number distribution and the ring-size statistics of two crystallized models.
(ii)
At T = 750K, a low fraction about 62% of 6-fold ring distribution reveals a heterogeneous nature of crystalline-amorphous coexistence obtained by isothermal-annealing of the amorphous state with a considerable portion of floating bonds (5-fold and 7-fold rings). Our simulated results here are in good agreement with these experiments and simulations in self-healing of amorphous silicon by thermal annealing technique [50] and data of annealed various defects of grown silicene on the Ag(111) surface at 500 K [81]. The formation and concentration of defects in a 2D material directly determine its performance, reproducibility, and reliability and even its potential of unveiling exceptional properties. For the supercooled liquid region, a sharp distribution with more than 85% six-membered rings and 95% atoms with Z = 3 indicated a homogenous crystallized structure. Previous numerical work [82] has shown that supercooled liquid silicon can crystallize within 10 ns while it is relaxed at 75% of T
m . The crucial role of free surfaces in the freezing process of supercooled liquids Si and Ge is revealed in [83]: Presence of free surfaces may enhance the nucleation rates. From this related evidence together with our data, time-induced crystallization of supercooled liquid silicene is confirmed on a time scale accessible.
(iii)
Remarkably, we find a significant amount of five and seven-membered rings corresponded with the coordination number of Z = 4 and small numbers of dangling bonds in the crystallized models. These dangling atoms or under-coordinated atoms are located mainly on the edge of the simulated model due to breaking bonds at the boundary of 2D layer, plus those located in adatom defects. As recent research in [73], those dangling bonds are highly reactive sites for attraction of impurities, which may be useful for modification of the electronic structure or improvement of silicene stability while edge dangling bonds could be stabilized with hydrogen atoms. Moreover, a conserved fraction of Stone-Wales and vacancy structural defects (five and seven-membered rings) in honeycomb dominated crystallized structure is easily obtained by long-time evolution of low-temperature model. The temperature dependence of defects in crystalline silicene sheet may be advantageous in control the desired impurities located in configuration of silicene by thermal rejuvenation. The existence formation and role of those defects will be observed and discussed later.

Further valuable information regarding local structural units and connectivity of amorphous-crystalline structures is provided by the bond-angle distribution. In Fig. 6 , we display the bond-angle distribution calculated of some crystallized models ranged from 750 K to 1650 K.

All observed bond-angle distributions of both supercooled and amorphous models slightly change with aging and exhibits the highest peak located at around 117° – 119.5° which is very close to the calculated value of the low buckled honeycomb structure silicene equals to 116.25° [84] and 116.4° [85] and compatible with 3D ones. However, the angular distribution of all aged simulation models illustrates a distinctly broad-ranged Δθ = 90° – 150°. The strong deviation in the main peak from 120° in crystalline silicene caused by its buckling and distorted honeycomb-like structure, including the existence of skew rings and more complicated local atomic configurations in the models, e.g. adatoms. In addition, the wide bond angle distributions of crystallization of various silica-silicate structures are validated in [50,51,86] and broader angular distribution also suggests a sp3/sp2 hybridization of the annealed silicene model [86]. As proposed in 3D amorphous silicon aging [51], strain energies depend on bond angle distortions (Δθ)2 and decreasing (Δθ)allows relaxation of the stored bond angle distortion energy leading to gradually drop of energy of the random network system.

2D visualization of the atomic configuration of the honeycomb silicene model obtained at 750 K and 1650 K after a long annealing for 8 ns (Fig. 7 ), the visualization of some specific defects (Table 2 ) and the buckling distribution (Fig. 8 ) provides good insights into the aging effect on the structure of glass-forming material. Based on 2D visualization presented in Fig. 7, some points can be drawn as follows:
(a)
First, in the region above glass transition T
g , structure of the obtained silicene (Fig. 7a) by annealing process is not a monocrystalline honeycomb, it exhibits a polycrystalline configuration which is the result of expansion of quenched-in crystalline clusters in liquid phase during supercooling process. MD simulation of monolayer silicene growth of isolated 2D clusters of Si atoms on the Ir(111) substrate surface provides a polycrystalline structure which is a sequel of growth of each cluster through adatom adhesion and associate with cluster migration and coalescence to form larger clusters [87]. Liu explained that the grain size of polycrystalline silicene will have a more vulnerable nature with mechanical properties and the efficiency of the annealing process depends on grain size [88]. Moreover, fairly common polycrystals of graphene - the carbon homologue of silicene are systematically studied by many experiments and MD simulations which already have markedly approved different characteristics [89–93].
(b)
As shown in Fig. 7, grain boundaries of polycrystalline 2D silicon show a vital role of liquid-like atoms (low-numbered chain defects) in control the grain size growth of nucleation during crystallization by aging technique which will be further analyzed in future work. In addition, natural rejuvenation silicene from the supercooled liquid state can provide great length local linear defect which may act as a center of the attraction of impurities. Among the common types of defects in silicene (single-vacancy, di-vacancy, S–W defects and adatoms) as pronounced in various investigate of finite silicene [39], concentration and location of those defective and distorted structures are confirmed by our data.
(c)
One can also see that the observed edge of single-layer silicene obtained by annealing from disorder state is complicated, which contains not only armchair or zigzag parts, but also contains various structural defects, including the mono- and di-vacancies or the dangling bonds (see Table 2 for more detailed shapes). Dangling bonds at the edge are reactive sites for oxidation and hydrogenation process and maybe alter the ballistic current and electronic structure of 2D nanoribbons [17,73]. So the impact of the imperfect edge of silicene needs to be carefully considered when deal with applied magnetic and electronic field band-gap control-technique.
(d)
On the other hand, crystallized models from the amorphous region (Fig. 7b) illustrate a more inhomogeneous combination of amorphous-crystalline structure as mentioned before, since the fraction of atoms involving in various defects, including vacancies of various types, adatoms, local linear defects, S–W defects, and skew rings located along with ordered hexagonal rings. The high concentrate of defects has a tendency to aggregate into clusters and chains located uniformly throughout silicene layer. The small-scale and separation of growth crystalline clusters from the amorphous phase compare to the one evolved from supercooled liquid shows a partial crystallization progress. This sequence of annealing of amorphous silicene is in good agreement with a recent work of T. Mizuguchi et al. [70]. In comparing with of defect types of other experiments and numerical works of silicene, we catalogue various types of structural defects, including adatoms, 5- and 7-fold rings, various sizes/shapes vacancies and various sizes/shapes ring size atoms as described in Table 2.

As mentioned in the introduction, the most stable low buckled-honeycomb structure of silicene found by DFT calculations has buckling equal to 0.44Å and a bond length of 2.88Å [40]. The presence of natural buckling of silicene indicates a clear preference for the sp3 rather than sp2 hybridization of Si atoms. DFT proposed buckled honeycomb lattice of silicene creates new capabilities for manipulating the electronic dispersion of silicene and thus it opens a controlled band gap by applying an electric field [94]. In our simulations, the crystalline phase of silicene recovered from supercooled liquid and amorphous state indeed exhibits a buckling behavior with the distribution of buckling ranged from 0 to 0.44Å. In Fig. 8, an important information pointed out from buckling behavior is the sequence decreasing of the buckling fluctuation degree of the crystalline network of silicon atoms after rearranging by themselves during relaxation at constant temperature. Note that our previous MD calculation of a-silicene and c-silicene obtained by cooling from the melt found a similar but considerably higher fluctuation buckling distribution [16,42]. The effect of the relaxation process of symmetrical behavior of buckled silicene is identified here as a tendency to weaken high buckled atoms which produce a homogeneous low-buckled silicene layer. This information has not yet been reported in the literature and the effect of low-buckled silicene after aging would be very interesting for further DFT calculations and experiments.

A comprehensive investigation of the crystallization of single layer silicene from the supercooled liquid and amorphous states has been carried out via MD simulation with Stillinger-Weber potential. Models of supercooled liquid and amorphous silicene at temperatures ranged from 750 K to 1650 K have been previously obtained by cooling from the melt at the appropriate cooling rate of 2 × 1013 K/s. In consequence, some essential conclusions can be reported:
•
Indeed, we clarify the aging phenomenon of two disorder phases of freestanding silicene in the supercooled liquid and amorphous region. Our estimation of the critical cooling rate of amorphous silicene is calculated by using the TTT diagram. This is also able to evaluate that supercooled liquid silicene is a low glass-forming material and it has a strong tendency to be crystallized. Our result here can be used as a reference to experimental development of the amorphous silicene material in the future for semiconductor application.
•
2D silicenes obtained via isothermal annealing have broadened angular distribution, homogeneous low-buckled degree and similar interatomic distance with bulk 3D silicon.
•
This work highlights a detailed picture of crystallization of disorder-to-order of promising 2D material – silicene. For the supercooled liquid phase, the system appears to be reconstructed to a polycrystalline configuration. While almost atoms in annealed systems at temperature above T
g exhibit the domination of honeycomb formation of 6-fold rings, aging effect indicates prominently a dependence of crystalline perfectness on annealed temperature: The relaxation at higher temperature above T
g will evolve to a higher-refined crystalline silicene sheet.
•
Still, evidence of crystalline-amorphous coexistence is presented after an isothermal-annealing process of amorphous silicene. A catalogue of specific and clusters of structural defects is illustrated, accompanied by their effects. It would be interesting to consider about the stability of various kinds of defects in aged silicene at temperatures below T
g : a-silicene may be recognized as a natural 2D semiconductor and provide band-gap controlled by the beneficence of adatoms, double vacancies or SW defects. Despite these slow rearrangements by aging, such specific defects are abundant and their abilities are believed substantial with temperature.
